column4: Hmf.  Ubuntu seems to be far more difficult to build packages on for non-developers, than for example SuSE.
With SuSE I just select the huge 'development' package-group, and i can compile almost everything at once.
checkinstall allows you to build deb packages (and rpms) from source
you can 'cheat' with 'checkinstall'
Explain, please. :-)
otherwise, yes it is more demanding than rolling RPMs AFAIK
Uhm, I don't even want to roll rpm's.. i just want to do "configure; make; make install" ;)
But most of the time, it seems I have to hunt down libraries and stuff.
oh, definitely checkout 'checkinstall' then
doing now.
yes, you'll have to satisfy dependencies to compile, as usual
Yups, but a lot of the really really basic stuff seems to be missing by default in ubuntu .. which is a pain ;)
example?
gcc
apt-get install build-essential
(IIRC)
did that.. and just installed libxv-dev .. which also seems like it should be there by default :)
meh
I know, i know. :)  Can't satisfy everybody.
But it would be really nice for us linux "amateurs" who've been using various distro for .. 8+ years .. :-)  to have an easy-to-install package that just shoveled in most of the necessities. :)
